abstracts.cdata!:
Sri Lanka policy makers had concentrated
            mainly on promoting universal access to primary education.
            The key areas of the reform program were the provision of
            education for all children aged 6-14 years (grades 1-9); the
            reduction of inequalities in the distribution of resources
            to public schools; the introduction of a new, child-centered
            curriculum for the primary cycle (grades 1-5); and the
            rationalization of facilities and expansion of learning
            resources to improve education quality. Primary school
            completion rates increased from 90 percent to 95 percent -
            which mean that 100,000 more students completed primary
            school each year, using a modernized curriculum with
            child-friendly learning. 200,000 more students completed
            grade 9 each year (up from 59 percent in 1996 to 78 percent
            in 2004), with gender parity. The government has designed a
            new education sector development framework and program
            (ESDFP) for general education, based on a five year rolling plan.
